channel.title: POLS/CSSS 501 (2018) on POLS 501: Advanced Political Research Design and Analysis
channel.description: Recent content in POLS/CSSS 501 (2018) on POLS 501: Advanced Political Research Design and Analysis

item.title: Proposal
item.description: Add the file doc/initial-proposal.md In a paragraph or two: State a research question. Describe what data you will use to answer the question. Discuss where and how will you get that data. Commit changes to GitHub. We will do this at the start of class

item.title: Proposal II
item.description: Instructions Add a Markdown or R Markdown file in your named doc/initial-proposal.md to your project repository. Answer the questions in the next section in that file. To submit the assignment, Commit and push all changes GitHub Open an issue in your project repository Title it “Review Project Proposal II” Assign the issue to @jrnold and @calvinhgarner Submit the issue See the Project Workflow. Proposal In one to two paragraphs propose a research project for this course.

item.title: Data Analysis I (Data Wrangling and EDA)
item.description: Exact instructions of directory organization to follow. The purpose of this assignment is to encourage you to find, load, clean, and explore your data before continuing to analysis. State your research question, and your expected research design to answer that question. What are your data sources? Cite the data appropriately using name or title of the data set, authors, version, creation date, and persistent data identifier (e.g. DOI) if available or URL if one is not.

item.title: Data Analysis 2
item.description: Write this asisgnment in a file named assignment-3.Rmd in your repository. It may-be useful to copy material the previous assignment as a starting point since this should be viewed as a draft towards your final project. To submit this assignment: Open a pull request titled “Review Data Analysis 2” Assign it to @jrnold and @CalvinGarner See the instructions on what to include in the comment. Instructions This assignment should be viewed as a step towards producing a final project.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Fork https://github.com/UW-POLS501/2018-assignment-1 Write your exercise answers in 2018-assignment-1.Rmd Commit both the R Markdown and the generated HTML files When ready, create a pull request with the title “Initial submission” Create a pull request We will cover the submission at the start of class on Tuesday. Exercise 1 QSS Exercise 1.5.1 Exercise 2 QSS Exercise 1.5.2 Exercise 3 QSS Exercise 2.8.3

item.title: CHANGELOG
item.description: See the GitHub repository the history of changes. 2018-01-24 Added Project Assignment 3 Added additional readings that had gotten removed in a previous commit. 2018-01-17 Added CHANGELOG file Posted Project Assignment 2

item.title: Getting Help with R
item.description: A good place to start is Rstudio’s guide for getting help with R Asking for Help When asking for help with R it is important to at least Include the exact code that you ran The error message that you got Without the code and the error message it can be hard to impossible to diagnose the problem and provide a solution. Questions such as “This isn’t working” or even “I’m getting this error message” aren’t useful without the code and error message.

item.title: Git and GitHub
item.description: For quick introduction on learn how to use Version control within RStudio, I suggest the “Version Control” chapter of the Working with the RStudio IDE (Part 2) DataCamp course. Relationship between GitHub and Local Git Projects References Jenny Bryan, Happy Git and GitHub for the useR DataCamp course Version Control with Git. This course requires shell knowledge, but the following two modules are useful. Automated Version Control Using Git from RStudio Simple guide to forks in GitHub and Git GitHub Help Git and GitHub videos for beginners from dataschool introduces git and GitHub via many videos.

item.title: Git: Assignment Submission and Workflow
item.description: Cloning, Pull Requests, Forking, Pulling, and Pushing See the Happy Git and GitHub for the useR chapter Fork a repo. Instructions Go to the course website, click Assignments. Scroll down to the Assignments section, click on the link to the assignment under Instructions and Submissions. Click on the Fork button to fork the repository to your GitHub account. Click Clone or download.

item.title: Git: Project Submission and Workflow
item.description:
For the project assignments, each student has a repository named UW-POLS501/:username where :username is the GitHub username of the student. This does not need to be forked. The student works directly on that repository, and submits assignments by opening an issue on UW-POLS501/:username/issue. {"x":{"diagram":"sequenceDiagram
 participant remote as UW-POLS501/student
 participant local as local repository
 remote-local: Clone repository
 Note over remote: Assignment 1
 loop Until completed
 local-local: Work and commit
 local-remote: Push changes
 end
 remote-remote: Open issue to submit
 Note over remote: Assignment 2
 loop Until completed
 local-local: Work and commit
 local-remote: Push changes
 end
 remote-remote: Open issue to submit"

item.title: How to avoid copying and pasting code by using functions, for loops and functionals
item.description: One of the most important principles in writing software is “don’t repeat yourself (DRY)”. This module covers using functions, for-loops, and functionals to avoid copying and pasting code. In addition to this, see the the R for Data Science chapters Functions a Iteration (for-loops and functions) for more detailed discussions of these concepts. Setup Consider the example from QSS Exercise 1. Review the explanations and instructions for that question. # a QSS Exercise from Chapter 1.

item.title: Installing R
item.description: Installing or Updating R Install R The R website is … special. Since you probably don’t know or care what a mirror is, here are links to the Go to the R Project website Choose the Download and install R your operation system: Mac: Download R-3.4.3.pkg Windows: First click on base and then on Download R 3.4.3 for Windows Upgrade R If you already have R installed, to check that you have the newest version of R, run

item.title: Notes on R for Data Science
item.description: Visualization Other resources: All the graph things Stat 545. Jenny Bryan. Tibbles Why might you want to create non-syntactic variable names? Since variable names are often used as in plots (e.g. axis-titles) or headers in tables, where having spaces or other characters that are invalid R variable names is useful. Those functions will have ways to use text other than the column, but using the non-syntactic variable name can be convenient.

item.title: Onboarding
item.description: Please complete the following before the first day of class. Sign up for our Slack channel. You should have received an invite. If not email the instructors. Sign up for a GitHub Fill out course survey using the course. The should have received an email with the link. A link is also posted on the Slack channel. Fill out the survey with office hour preferences. See the email sent to the class or the Slack channel for a link.

item.title: References
item.description: Articles and books references in this course. Download these references as bibtex file here. Angrist, Joshua D, and Jörn-Steffen Pischke. 2010. “The Credibility Revolution in Empirical Economics: How Better Research Design Is Taking the Con Out of Econometrics.” Journal of Economic Perspectives 24 (2). American Economic Association: 3–30. doi:10.1257/jep.24.2.3. Bailey, Michael A., Anton Strezhnev, and Erik Voeten. 2016. “Estimating Dynamic State Preferences from United Nations Voting Data.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 61 (2).
